qas.question: What philosophy is a naturalist school?
What is the definition of paramanu in Hindu philosophy?
By understanding what does Vaisesika school believe one gains knowledge and liberation?
Who is credited with the Vaisesika darsana?
When was the Vaisesika darsana  produced?
What theory postulates that objects cannot be reduced?

plausible_answers.text: complete understanding of the world of experience

qas.question: What does Vaisesika say prevents knowledge and liberation?
Who discredited the idea of Vaisesika?

context: The <a0_0><b5_0>Vaiśeṣika<b5_0/><a0_0/> philosophy is a naturalist school; it is a form of atomism in natural philosophy. It postulated that all objects in the physical universe are reducible to paramāṇu (<a1_0><b6_0>atoms<b6_0/><a1_0/>), and one's experiences are derived from the interplay of substance (a function of atoms, their number and their spatial arrangements), quality, activity, commonness, particularity and inherence. Knowledge and liberation was achievable by <b8_0>complete understanding of the <a2_0>world of experience<b8_0/><a2_0/>, according to Vaiśeṣika school . The Vaiśeṣika darśana is credited to <a3_0><b7_0><b9_0>Kaṇāda Kaśyapa<b9_0/><b7_0/><a3_0/> from the second half of the <a4_0>first millennium BCE<a4_0/>. The foundational text, the Vaiśeṣika Sūtra, opens as follows,
